channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: As China’s Propaganda Push Continues, Wuhan Emerges as a Star
item.description: New television shows have paid tribute to the city where the coronavirus emerged, focusing on residents’ heroism and glossing over official mistakes.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The opera “Angel’s Diary” in Wuhan, China, last month. It pays tribute to the doctors on the frontlines at the start of the pandemic.

item.title: In the Netherlands, a Cartoon in School Leads to Online Threats and an Arrest
item.description: Threats against a high school teacher who displayed a political cartoon that supported the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo have alarmed Dutch officials.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Claire Moses
item.media:description: A woman was arrested on suspicion of making online threats against a teacher in the Dutch city of Rotterdam.

item.title: Attacks in France Point to a Threat Beyond Extremist Networks
item.description: The most recent attackers were isolated, self-radicalized individuals. That has raised questions about the government’s response.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi, Constant Méheut and Layli Foroudi
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial for the victims of the Oct. 29 attack at the Notre-Dame basilica in Nice, France, that left three people dead.

item.title: Ethiopia's War With Its Tigray Region: Explained
item.description: What led the prime minister, Abiy Ahmed, to initiate a military campaign against the powerful Tigray region of Ethiopia, and what are the likely consequences for the country and the Horn of Africa?
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Flags representing the Tigray region of Ethiopia lining a wall in the Tigrayan city of Mekele. The region has experienced rising tensions with the federal government.

item.title: U.S. Election Is a High-Stakes Political Struggle. In Russia.
item.description: The Kremlin’s allies, long accustomed to hearing accusations of rigged Russian votes, have used President Trump’s contentions of fraud to turn the tables. But the Kremlin’s critics are firing back.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters rallying in Philadelphia on Thursday in support of the ongoing ballot count inside the Pennsylvania Convention Center.

item.title: Australia Quiet on First Foreign-Meddling Arrest, but Target Is Clear
item.description: The suspect, who has been active in Chinese-Australian groups, was charged under laws against foreign interference that were seen as a response to China.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: James Ross/Australian Associated Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Di Sanh Duong in Melbourne, Australia, in June.

item.title: An Afghan Mayor Expected to Die. Instead, She Lost Her Father.
item.description: Zarifa Ghafari, one of the few female mayors in Afghanistan, has been subjected to death threats and assassination attempts, and believes her father was gunned down because of her.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Faizi and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zarifa Ghafari of Maidan Shar, Afghanistan, at a meeting with municipal officials in April 2019.

item.title: A Monthly Basic Income Check Changed His Life. Now He Sends Out 650.
item.description: Michael Bohmeyer’s website, “My Basic Income,” has given randomly selected people almost $1,200 a month for a year to see if it improves their lives. His answer: Yes.
item.dc:creator: Sally McGrane
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Bohmeyer, center, riding his bicycle in the office of “My Basic Income,” the website he founded to provide a monthly basic income for 600 randomly selected people. Moving helps him think, he said.

item.title: Myanmar Prepares for a Troubled Election: 'This Is Not Democracy'
item.description: The vote on Sunday will render a verdict not only on the country’s fragile constitutional settlement but also on its civilian leader, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Saw Nang
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Supporters of the National League for Democracy carrying a portrait of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, now Myanmar’s civilian leader, this month.

item.title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Lebanese Politician Allied With Hezbollah
item.description: The action continued the administration’s efforts to dial up pressure against Tehran before the end of President Trump’s term.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: The action against Gibran Bassil was the latest by the United States against political figures in Lebanon who are said to be linked with Hezbollah.

item.title: Eta Moves Over Caribbean, Leaving Devastation in Its Wake
item.description: Central American nations talled the displaced and the dead after landslides and flooding. Dozens of people, from Guatemala to Panama, have died.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: The Red Cross evacuated people near the Bambito River, north of Panama City, on Thursday.

item.title: A Lockdown With Loopholes: England Faces New Virus Restrictions
item.description: The government has put the new rules in place to address a surging number of coronavirus cases across the country, but some shops and companies, as well as consumers, are flouting them.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for a bus by the Barbican in central London on Thursday, the first day of the new lockdown in Britain.

item.title: Suspect Arrested in Deadly Ambush of Mormon Family
item.description: A year after the attack, nobody has been convicted of the crime, infuriating relatives and casting further doubt on the Mexican justice system.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: The burial last year of Dawna Ray and her two children Trevor, 11, and Rogan, 2, who were among the nine victims of the killing. No one has been convicted in the case.

item.title: Gigi Proietti, Actor Who Embodied the Roman Spirit, Dies at 80
item.description: Beloved in Italy, he was best known as the star of a TV series playing a small-town police chief. He also had a long film career and a popular one-man stage show.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Gigi Proietti, one of Italy’s most beloved actors, in 1995 in his best-known role, as a police chief in the comedy-drama series “Il Maresciallo Rocca.”

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A second day with more than 100,000 cases in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Lous and the Yakuza Makes Music From Her Life’s Darkness
item.description: At 24, the songwriter, singer and rapper has fled one war and lived through the aftermath of another. Now, bridging continents, she tells an autobiographical story with her debut album.
item.dc:creator: Geneva Abdul
item.media:description: “I like to describe my music as a constant search for truth,” said Marie-Pierra Kakoma, who records as Lous and the Yakuza.

item.title: A Good Night for Biden
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Hawaii’s reopening may be good for tourism. Is it good for locals?
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:description: A nearly empty beach in Honolulu early in October, when all visitors were required to quarantine.

item.title: A lockdown with loopholes: Some flout new restrictions in England.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for food outside a cafe in London on Thursday.

item.title: A nasal spray prevented Covid-19 infection in ferrets, a study finds.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.media:description: Ferrets are used by scientists studying flu, SARS and other respiratory diseases because the animals can catch viruses through the nose much like humans do.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Counting continues in the U.S. election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee for president, spoke in Wilmington, Del., on Thursday.

item.title: American Tribalism, Australian Reflections
item.description: Watching the United States choose a president from Sydney, our correspondent wonders: When will all the division end?
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Olivia Locher for The New York Times

item.title: Guatemala Mudslides Kill More Than 50
item.description: Another 23 people across Central America have died or are missing as a result of a vast storm system dumping heavy rainfall across the region.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: The flooded streets of Puerto Barrios, Guatemala, on Thursday.

item.title: E.S. Reddy, Who Led U.N.’s Efforts Against Apartheid, Dies at 96
item.description: An Indian-born acolyte of Gandhi, he campaigned for boycotts, divestments and other protests against the South African government.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Children Produce Weaker Coronavirus Antibodies, Study Finds
item.description: The research suggests that children clear the infection much faster than adults and may help explain why many don’t become seriously ill.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children seem to clear the infection must faster than adults and may be infectious for a shorter period of time.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Joe Biden is gaining ground.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
item.media:description: Travellers at Beijing Daxing International Airport in September.

item.title: In Covid-Wrecked Mexico, One Doctor Tried Humor and Home Visits
item.description: Gustavo Gutiérrez is a one-man roving medical clinic in Reynosa, developing a rare practice in the turbulent times of the coronavirus. He’s visited scores of patients fearful of the hospital.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Gustavo Gutiérrez checking on a Covid-19 patient. By his count, he’s seen well over 200 patients in their homes since June.

item.title: Afghan War Casualty Report: November 2020
item.description: At least 37 pro-government forces and 76 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
item.dc:creator: Fatima Faizi
item.media:credit: Farzana Wahidy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fahima Haidari, a Kabul University student, studying the ruins of a classroom after an attack that killed at least 33 people.

item.title: Ethiopia Escalates Fight Against Its Powerful Tigray Region
item.description: Clashes broke out between the federal military forces and local security units in the northern region of Tigray, where the ruling party has defied the authority of Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
item.media:credit: Ethiopian Public Broadcaster, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed of Ethiopia ordered a surprise military offensive against the government of the country’s northern Tigray region in a national broadcast on Wednesday.

item.title: Cutting Greenhouse Gases From Food Production Is Urgent, Scientists Say
item.description: Efforts to limit global warming often focus on emissions from fossil fuels, but food is crucial, too, according to new research.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: George Steinmetz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cattle in Hereford, Texas, being shipped to a slaughterhouse. Global emissions from food amount to roughly 30 percent of humanity’s carbon output.

item.title: North Korea Tells Its People to Stop Smoking. But What About Kim Jong-un?
item.description: The country is expanding a national campaign against the habit, even as state news media continues to show Mr. Kim puffing away on the subway, at schools and at children’s hospitals.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Outside a supermarket in central Pyongyang, North Korea, in 2018. More than 46 percent of adult men in North Korea were smokers in 2017, according to the World Health Organization.

item.title: Kosovo President Resigns to Fight War Crimes Case in the Netherlands
item.description: Hashim Thaci was a guerrilla leader during Kosovo’s battle for independence from Serbia in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Hashim Thaci of Kosovo greeting supporters after returning from the Netherlands in July. He has previously denied the accusations against him.

item.title: A mutation in the virus has prompted Denmark to kill millions of infected mink.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Denmark has already begun killing all mink at 400 farms that were either infected, or close enough to infected farms, to cause concern.

item.title: The President Versus Democracy
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times

item.title: For the Arts in Europe, Lockdown Feels Different This Time
item.description: Many of the continent’s museums, theaters, concert halls and bookshops have been forced to close again, and now, people’s reactions have changed.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: With France now in a second lockdown, cultural landmarks like the Louvre museum are again closed to the public.

item.title: Emotional reunions follow the early release of N.J. inmates, in an effort to contain the virus.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully, Nate Schweber and Kevin Armstrong
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kristyne Garcia with her husband, Obiora Orange, after he was released from prison on Wednesday.

item.title: Midwestern voters say they feared the virus, but some worried more about the economy.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Sarah Mervosh and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for the polls to open at a recreation center in Columbus, Ohio.

item.title: The virus crisis dredges up a single mother’s old regrets and fears.
item.media:credit: Zerb Mellish for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrea Luttrell, with her son, Towns, in their living room in Farmers Branch, Texas.

item.title: Online posts from expats in France find an increased audience among stressed Americans.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Meltzer

item.title: Norway’s Supreme Court Hears Rights Challenge to Arctic Oil Drilling
item.description: Environmental groups argue that exploratory drilling licenses violate a constitutional right to a healthy environment. It’s a test case taking on an industry that is key to the country’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Henrik Pryser Libell and Isabella Kwai
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mathias Svold for The New York Times
item.media:description: Most of the licenses environmental groups are fighting were granted in the Barents Sea.

item.title: Should You Move to France? Ask an Expat Blogger
item.description: “Frenchfluencers” (expats who blog or post from France) report increased engagement from stressed Americans seeking escapism.
item.dc:creator: Marisa Meltzer

item.title: U.S. Election, Poland, Coronavirus: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: 100,000 cases in a single day push the U.S. into new terrain.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bicyclist passing the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: No matter who wins the U.S. election, Mr. Trump will lead the virus response for the next few months.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg

item.title: Denmark Will Kill All Farmed Mink, Citing Covid Infections
item.description: Government officials said on Wednesday that a mutation in the virus could interfere with vaccine effectiveness in humans.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Mink on a farm in Gjoel, Denmark, last month.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The latest U.S. election updates.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
item.media:description: At a bar in Canberra on Wednesday.

item.title: Ancient Remains in Peru Reveal Female Big-Game Hunter
item.description: Scientists are divided on broader implications of the find for ancient gender roles.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: Excavations at the Wilamaya Patjxa site in Peru, where archaeologists recovered roughly 20,000 artifacts, including the remains of six people, one of whom was the female hunter.

item.title: Tropical Storm Eta Left at Least 3 Dead in Central America
item.description: After hitting Nicaragua as a Category 4 hurricane, Eta weakened, but continued to dump torrential rain in the region.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Damages caused by the passage of Hurricane Eta in Puerto Cabezas, Nicaragua, on Wednesday.

item.title: Poland Delays a Near-Total Ban on Abortion
item.description: The move came after two weeks of protests that were the most intense in the country since the 1989 collapse of communism.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Outraged by a court decision that effectively banned nearly all abortions in Poland, thousands of people took to the streets.

item.title: Bolsonaro’s Eldest Son, a Senator, Faces Graft Charges in Brazil
item.description: Flávio Bolsonaro has been under investigation on suspicion of running a kickback scheme that has embroiled several members of the family, including the first lady.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: Flávio Bolsonaro, the eldest son of President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, has been charged with graft. He was elected to the senate in 2018, the same year his father won the presidency.

item.title: As Italy’s Eateries Closed Early, a Small Neighbor Became a Dinner Hot Spot
item.description: Local officials fear that diners traveling to San Marino, a small independent nation, will spread the coronavirus. A new curfew in Italy may slow the mealtime trend.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: San Marino in 2017. “Viruses travel quickly, disregarding borders and frontiers,” 15 mayors from bordering Italian towns wrote in a letter urging the small nation to match Italy’s pandemic restrictions.

item.title: The Latest on the Election
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers sort through ballots at the Pennsylvania Convention Center.

item.title: Arnab Goswami, TV Journalist, Is Arrested in Mumbai
item.description: The conservative anchor Arnab Goswami was detained on charges of abetting a suicide in Mumbai, where an opposition party is in power.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: Arnab Goswami, shown in 2015, is an outspoken supporter of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalist government.

item.title: A Transfixed World Awaits What’s Next in America
item.description: As U.S. results trickled in, they were analyzed far and wide with the sort of blanket news coverage most often reserved for elections closer to home.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Damien Cave
item.media:description: Advertising screens in London promoted radio coverage of the U.S. presidential election.

item.title: Having Made Peace Abroad, Ethiopia’s Leader Goes to War at Home
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, began a sweeping military operation against one of his own regions.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Simon Marks
item.media:description: Police officers in Mekelle, a city in the Tigray region of Ethiopia, in February.

item.title: U.S. Quits Paris Climate Agreement: Questions and Answers
item.description: President Trump’s withdrawal formally came into force the day after Election Day in the United States. Here’s what it means.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students from the Washington area participated in a youth climate strike on Capitol Hill in March 2019.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: U.S. election special: A tighter race than many expected.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators and onlookers near the White House in Washington on Tuesday night.

item.title: South Korea Detains North Korean Who Crossed Demilitarized Zone
item.description: The man breached the Koreas’ heavily armed land border, triggering an extensive manhunt in the South, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers at the Demilitarized Zone last year.

item.title: Voters who saw containing the coronavirus as the most important issue favored Biden
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Giovanni Russonello
item.media:description: Joe Biden, the Democratic nominee for president, spoke to supporters in Philadelphia on Tuesday.

item.title: Vienna Reels From a Rare Terrorist Attack
item.description: The gunman, who killed four people and wounded 23, had been arrested for trying to join ISIS, raising questions about whether he should have been closely watched.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold, Melissa Eddy and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathering on Tuesday night in Stephansplatz, a square in Vienna, to pay tribute to the victims.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The U.S. has a pivotal day for the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
